title: Bobby Beaton
text:
Robert Beaton (June 19, 1912 – June 11, 2007) was an <a href="Atlantic%20Canada">Atlantic Canadian</a> <a href="ice%20hockey">hockey player</a>, <a href="boxing">boxer</a> and boxing referee.
Hockey.
Beaton was born in <a href="Port%20Hood%2C%20Nova%20Scotia">Port Hood</a>, <a href="Cape%20Breton%20Island">Cape Breton Island</a> and played hockey in Atlantic Canada in the early 1930s. He moved to <a href="England">England</a> in 1938 to play for the Stratham Lions and <a href="Brighton%20Tigers">Brighton Tigers</a>, winning the European Championship in <a href="Berlin">Berlin</a>. The next year he played for the Falkirk Lions of <a href="Scotland">Scotland</a>. Returning home to <a href="Nova%20Scotia">Nova Scotia</a>, Canada, he played and coached teams in <a href="Pictou%2C%20Nova%20Scotia">Pictou</a>, <a href="Truro%2C%20Nova%20Scotia">Truro</a>, <a href="Stellarton%2C%20Nova%20Scotia">Stellarton</a> and <a href="New%20Glasgow%2C%20Nova%20Scotia">New Glasgow</a>, winning seven A.P.C. (Antigonish, Pictou, Colchester league) titles, three Nova Scotia Championships and three Maritime titles in the 1940s and 1950s.
Boxing.
Beaton boxed professionally as a <a href="welterweight">welterweight</a> and his record was 12–0 with nine <a href="knockout">TKO</a>s. In 1941 he began refereeing. Until his retirement in 1983, he officiated at over 500 boxing bouts, including 41 Canadian, five British Commonwealth and one World Championship. Beaton is credited with conceiving the three-judge system in boxing, now standard practice in the sport. He was Referee-in-Chief and Adviser to the Nova Scotia Boxing Authority from 1978 until 1994.
Hall-of-Fame inductions.
Beaton was inducted into the <a href="Canadian%20Boxing%20Hall%20of%20Fame">Canadian Boxing Hall of Fame</a>, the Nova Scotia Sports Heritage Hall of Fame, the Pictou County Sports Heritage Hall of Fame and the Cape Breton Sports Heritage Hall of Fame.
